Research

In today's activity you will choose the most important questions from your scoping table to research. As a reminder, your table contains:

  • natural questions, questions about the environment, and explore where your water comes from and how it gets to you
  • social questions, questions about people and communities, and explore how people use water in their daily lives, or
  • technical questions, questions about the design process, and explore existing solutions to water conservation

Choose Research Questions

Choose two questions from your scoping table that you want to research. You will be researching using sources on the internet to answer these questions so choose questions that you could answer using internet research. Copy your questions in the "Research Questions" text box below and indicate whether they are natural, social, or design questions. (You can always add questions to your scoping table so if you have other questions you want to research today you can add them to your table now.)

Research Notes

1. Access the research resources

  • Open the Water Conservation Research Google Doc: Water Conservation: Research Articles
  • Look through the different topic sections to find resources related to your research questions.
  • Topics are organized by themes. For example, water quality, water usage, conservation methods, and more.

2. Choose your first article [either any that match their selected RQ or one of the two from the first section]

  • Select one resource article from the Good Doc that best matches your research question
  • You can choose which article you want to read based on the title and description provided or you could open and skim the articles first and then choose the best one for you.
  • If you are not sure which one to read first, read either " How Do We Use Water? (United States Environmental Protection Agency)" OR " How Do We Get Our Drinking Water in the U.S.? (National Public Radio)"
  • In the research notes table below, write down: the title and source of your first article

3. Complete your initial research

  • Read your chosen article.
  • Then complete your Research Notes with information from the article. Note anything you learned that is relevant to the question. It's possible that this article did not answer your research question fully, so also make a note of any information you still want to learn.

4. Choose your second article

  • Pick at least one additional article from the Google Doc
  • Choose one that will help answer the research questions you still have
  • If none of the provided articles match what you need, ask your teacher for permission to search for your own article using Google.
  • If searching on your own:

Remember, not all articles will give you the correct information

Check that your source is reliable (look for .gox, .edu., or well-known organizations)

Ask yourself: Who wrote this? Why did they write it? Is this source trustworthy?

If you are unsure if a source is reliable or not, discuss your source with a classmate or teacher

  • In the research notes table below, write down: the title and source of your second article in the second column. Then complete your Research Notes with information from the article.

4. Optional third article:

  • If you want to learn more, choose a third research article from the Google Doc or find your own with the instructions provided earlier
  • Add another column to your Research Notes table for this additional research
